core_concept.principle: SHM Graphical Analysis: x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ), v(t) = -ωA sin(ωt + φ), a(t) = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ), Graphical differentiation: v = dx/dt, a = dv/dt, Graphical integration: x = ∫v dt, v = ∫a dt, Phase shifts: v leads x by 90°, a leads x by 180°

sections.introduction: Analyzing displacement as a function of time through graphical representations, including amplitude, period, phase, and initial conditions.

key_concept.definition: Position-time graphs, Sinusoidal curves, Amplitude, Period, Phase constant, Initial conditions, Graphical parameters
key_concept.context: Position-time graphs for SHM display perfect sinusoidal patterns characterized by amplitude (vertical scale), period (horizontal timing), and phase constant (horizontal shift), providing complete visual information about the oscillation.

classifications.value: Classification based on graphical features and parameter extraction
classifications.behavior: Different position graph features convey specific information: amplitude shows maximum displacement, period indicates oscillation timing, phase shift reveals starting position, and waveform shape distinguishes between cosine and sine functions

examples.explanation: Extracting amplitude, period, and phase constant from position-time graphs
Determining phase constant from initial position and graph characteristics

classifications.note: Position graph: x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ) or x(t) = A sin(ωt + φ), Amplitude A = maximum displacement, Period T = time for one cycle, Phase φ determines horizontal shift, Angular frequency ω = 2π/T

principles.statement: Position-time graphs exhibit characteristic sinusoidal patterns: Basic Form: x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ) or x(t) = A sin(ωt + φ); Cosine function common for release from amplitude. Graphical Features: Amplitude (A): Maximum vertical displacement; Measured from equilibrium; Units: meters. Period (T): Time for one complete cycle; Horizontal distance between corresponding points; T = 2π/ω. Frequency (f): f = 1/T; Number of cycles per second. Phase Constant (φ): Horizontal shift of the curve; Determines initial position; x(0) = A cosφ. Special Cases: φ = 0: x(t) = A cos(ωt) - starts at maximum; φ = π/2: x(t) = A cos(ωt + π/2) = -A sin(ωt) - starts at equilibrium moving negative; φ = π: x(t) = A cos(ωt + π) = -A cos(ωt) - starts at negative maximum. Reading Graphs: Maximum points: x = +A; Minimum points: x = -A; Zero crossings: equilibrium positions; Slope indicates velocity. Parameter Extraction: From graph: A = (max - min)/2; T = time between successive maxima; φ from initial position: cosφ = x(0)/A. Multiple Representations: Same motion can be represented by cosine or sine with appropriate phase; Choice based on convenience.
principles.application: Sketch position graphs from equations. Extract parameters from given graphs. Determine phase constants from initial conditions. Convert between cosine and sine representations. Analyze graphical features to understand motion. Solve problems using graphical information.
principles.example: Sketch x(t) = 0.1 cos(4t) graph. Extract A, T, ω from position graph. Determine equation from graphical data. Analyze initial conditions from graph shape.
principles.analogy: Like watching a Ferris wheel from the side - the height of a specific seat follows a perfect up-down wave pattern, with the highest points showing amplitude, the time between reaching the same height showing period, and where the seat starts determining the phase shift of the pattern

worked_examples.title: Analyzing Position-Time Graph
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph for SHM shows maximum displacement 0.08 m, minimum -0.08 m, with successive maxima at t = 0.5 s and t = 2.0 s. At t = 0, x = 0.04 m moving positive. Determine the SHM equation.

step_by_step.explanation: T = time between maxima = 2.0 - 0.5 = 1.5 s
x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ) = 0.08 cos(4.1888t + φ)

step_by_step.step: Determine correct phase using initial velocity

step_by_step.explanation: Moving positive at t=0, so v(0) > 0, therefore sin(φ) < 0
φ = -π/3 gives sin(-π/3) = -√3/2 < 0, so v(0) > 0 ✓; φ = π/3 gives sin(π/3) > 0, so v(0) < 0 ✗

worked_examples.final_answer: x(t) = 0.08 cos(4.19t - π/3) m; All graphical parameters used to determine equation

worked_examples.title: Sketching Position Graphs
worked_examples.problem: Sketch position-time graphs for: (a) x(t) = 0.06 cos(5t), (b) x(t) = 0.06 sin(5t), (c) x(t) = 0.06 cos(5t + π/2). Label key features and compare the graphs.

step_by_step.explanation: All have A = 0.06 m, ω = 5 rad/s, T = 2π/5 = 1.257 s
Cosine with φ = 0; Starts at maximum: x(0) = 0.06 m; Maximum at t=0, T, 2T...; Minimum at t=T/2, 3T/2...
Sine function; Equivalent to cosine with φ = -π/2; x(0) = 0; Starting at equilibrium moving positive; Maximum at t=T/4; Minimum at t=3T/4
Cosine with φ = π/2; x(0) = 0.06 cos(π/2) = 0; Equivalent to -0.06 sin(5t); Starting at equilibrium moving negative; Maximum at t=3T/4; Minimum at t=T/4
(b) leads (a) by π/2 (90°); (c) lags (a) by π/2? Wait, (c) = 0.06 cos(5t + π/2) = -0.06 sin(5t), while (b) = +0.06 sin(5t), so (c) is opposite to (b)
All graphs have same amplitude and period; Differ only in horizontal shifts; (a) starts at max; (b) starts at zero going up; (c) starts at zero going down
(b) is shifted left from (a) by T/4; (c) is shifted right from (a) by T/4? Check: cos(5t + π/2) = cos(5(t + π/10)) = cos(5(t + T/4)), so actually shifted left by T/4
cos(5t + π/2) = cos(5(t + π/10)) but π/10 = T/4? T=2π/5=1.257 s, T/4=0.314 s, π/10=0.314 s ✓; So (c) is shifted left from (a) by T/4, same as (b) but with negative amplitude

worked_examples.final_answer: All graphs have A=0.06 m, T=1.26 s; (a) starts at max, (b) and (c) both shifted by T/4 from (a) but (c) has opposite sign; Phase constants create horizontal shifts

sections.introduction: Analyzing velocity-time and acceleration-time graphs in SHM, their phase relationships, and connections through graphical calculus.

key_concept.definition: Velocity-time graphs, Acceleration-time graphs, Phase relationships, Graphical differentiation, Graphical integration, Slope and area interpretations
key_concept.context: Velocity and acceleration graphs for SHM also display sinusoidal patterns but with specific phase shifts relative to position, and these graphs are mathematically connected through differentiation and integration operations.

image.caption: Velocity and acceleration as functions of time in SHM

classifications.value: Classification based on calculus connections between position, velocity, and acceleration
classifications.behavior: Different graphical relationships follow specific calculus rules: velocity graph slope gives acceleration, position graph slope gives velocity, area under acceleration graph gives velocity change, and area under velocity graph gives displacement, with consistent phase shifts between the graphs

examples.explanation: Deriving velocity from position graph slopes and acceleration from velocity graph slopes
Determining position from velocity graph area and velocity from acceleration graph area

classifications.note: Velocity: v(t) = dx/dt = -ωA sin(ωt + φ), Acceleration: a(t) = dv/dt = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ), Phase: v leads x by 90°, a leads x by 180°, Amplitude: v_max = ωA, a_max = ω²A

principles.statement: Velocity and acceleration graphs exhibit specific relationships: Velocity Graph: v(t) = -ωA sin(ωt + φ); Sinusoidal shape; Amplitude v_max = ωA; Phase: leads position by 90°; Zero at position extremes; Maximum at equilibrium. Acceleration Graph: a(t) = -ω²A cos(ωt + φ) = -ω²x(t); Sinusoidal shape; Amplitude a_max = ω²A; Phase: leads position by 180° (opposite phase); Maximum at position extremes; Zero at equilibrium. Graphical Differentiation: Slope of position graph = velocity; Slope of velocity graph = acceleration; Maximum slope occurs at zero crossings; Zero slope at extremes. Graphical Integration: Area under velocity graph = displacement; Area under acceleration graph = velocity change; Net area over one cycle = 0. Phase Relationships: When position at maximum, velocity = 0, acceleration at negative maximum; When position at equilibrium, velocity at maximum, acceleration = 0; Consistent 90° increments. Energy Relationships: Kinetic energy ∝ v²; Potential energy ∝ x²; Total energy constant. Reading the Graphs: Velocity zero crossings correspond to position maxima/minima; Acceleration zero crossings correspond to position zero crossings; Acceleration maxima correspond to position minima. Parameter Extraction: From v(t) graph: v_max = ωA, so ω = v_max/A; From a(t) graph: a_max = ω²A, so ω = √(a_max/A).
principles.application: Sketch velocity and acceleration graphs from position. Determine phase relationships between graphs. Apply graphical differentiation and integration. Extract system parameters from graphs. Analyze energy from velocity graphs. Solve problems using multiple graphs.
principles.example: Sketch v(t) and a(t) for given x(t). Determine acceleration from position graph slope. Calculate displacement from velocity graph area. Extract ω and A from graphical data.
principles.analogy: Like the relationship between distance, speed, and acceleration on a car trip - the distance graph shows where you are, its slope (steepness) shows your speed, and the slope of the speed graph shows acceleration; for SHM, these relationships become perfectly rhythmic and predictable

worked_examples.title: Complete Graphical Analysis
worked_examples.problem: For x(t) = 0.04 cos(10t) m, sketch position, velocity, and acceleration graphs on the same axes. Identify key points and verify relationships.

step_by_step.explanation: x(t) = 0.04 cos(10t); Cosine starting at maximum; x_max = 0.04 m, x_min = -0.04 m
Negative sine function; v_max = 0.4 m/s; Leads position by 90° (T/4 = 0.157 s); Zero at t=0, T/2, T...; Maximum at t=T/4, 3T/4...
a(t) = dv/dt = -0.4×10 cos(10t) = -4 cos(10t) m/s²
Negative cosine; a_max = 4 m/s²; Leads position by 180° (T/2 = 0.314 s); Opposite phase to position; Maximum negative at t=0; Zero at t=T/4, 3T/4...
t=0: x=+max, v=0, a=-max; t=T/4: x=0, v=-max, a=0; t=T/2: x=-max, v=0, a=+max; t=3T/4: x=0, v=+max, a=0
v leads x by 90°: cos(10t) vs -sin(10t) = cos(10t + π/2) ✓; a leads x by 180°: cos(10t) vs -cos(10t) = cos(10t + π) ✓
All graphs sinusoidal with same period; Different amplitudes; Specific phase shifts; Velocity zero when position at extremes; Acceleration zero when position at equilibrium

worked_examples.final_answer: Three graphs with T=0.628 s: x(t) amplitude 0.04 m, v(t) amplitude 0.4 m/s, a(t) amplitude 4 m/s²; v leads x by 90°, a leads x by 180°; All relationships verified

worked_examples.title: Graphical Differentiation Application
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph for SHM shows a maximum of 0.12 m at t=0 and crosses zero at t=0.2 s with negative slope. Find the velocity and acceleration at t=0.3 s using graphical methods.

step_by_step.explanation: A = 0.12 m; From t=0 (max) to t=0.2 s (zero): this is T/4, so T = 4×0.2 = 0.8 s
Starts at maximum, so φ = 0; x(t) = 0.12 cos(7.854t)
At t=0.3 s (between zero and minimum): position negative, velocity negative (moving toward more negative), acceleration positive (slowing down toward turning point)
Slope of x(t) at t=0.3 s should equal v(0.3); From graph, between t=0.2 s (x=0) and t=0.4 s (x=-0.12), slope ≈ -0.12/0.2 = -0.6 m/s, close to -0.667 m/s ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: At t=0.3 s: x = -0.0849 m, v = -0.667 m/s, a = +5.24 m/s²; Graphical methods consistent with analytical results

classifications.value: Classification based on energy visualization and analysis methods

classifications.note: Kinetic energy: K(t) = ½mω²A² sin²(ωt + φ), Potential energy: U(t) = ½kA² cos²(ωt + φ), Total energy: E = ½kA² constant, Energy graphs oscillate at 2ω frequency

principles.principle: Energy Graphs and Advanced Graphical Analysis
principles.statement: Energy graphs and advanced techniques provide deep insight: Energy-Time Graphs: K(t) = ½mω²A² sin²(ωt + φ); U(t) = ½kA² cos²(ωt + φ); E_total = constant; K and U oscillate out of phase. Energy Graph Characteristics: Both K and U always positive; Sum constant; Frequency = 2ω (double position frequency); K maximum when U minimum and vice versa. Damped Energy Graphs: E(t) = E₀e^(-bt/m); Exponential decay; Amplitude of K and U oscillations decreases; Total energy decreases smoothly. Graphical Problem Solving: Use graphs to determine unknown parameters; Apply graphical calculus to find relationships; Use area and slope methods; Solve problems visually. Real Data Analysis: Experimental graphs may show imperfections; Noise in measurements; Small damping always present; Non-ideal spring behavior possible. Phase Space Plots: Plot velocity vs position; Elliptical patterns for SHM; Area related to energy; Useful for analyzing complex motion. Advanced Techniques: Logarithmic plots for exponential decay; Fourier analysis for complex waveforms; Curve fitting to extract parameters; Computer-based graphical analysis. Interpretation Skills: Read graphs accurately; Identify key features; Extract quantitative information; Recognize patterns and anomalies; Apply physical principles to graphical data.
principles.application: Sketch and interpret energy-time graphs. Analyze damped oscillations graphically. Extract parameters from experimental data. Use graphical methods to solve problems. Apply phase space analysis. Use advanced graphical techniques.
principles.example: Sketch K(t) and U(t) for given x(t). Determine damping from amplitude decay. Analyze real pendulum data. Use graphical methods to find unknown frequency.
principles.analogy: Like monitoring the energy flow in a perfectly efficient factory - the 'kinetic energy' of active workers and the 'potential energy' of stored materials constantly exchange but the total value remains the same, while in a real factory (damped system) there's always some energy loss, and graphs help managers optimize the process

worked_examples.title: Energy Graph Analysis
worked_examples.problem: For a spring-mass system with x(t) = 0.05 cos(8t) m and m = 0.2 kg, sketch and analyze the kinetic, potential, and total energy graphs.

step_by_step.explanation: A = 0.05 m, ω = 8 rad/s, m = 0.2 kg
K(t) = ½mω²A² sin²(ωt) = ½ × 0.2 × 64 × 0.0025 sin²(8t) = 0.016 sin²(8t) J
U(t) = ½kA² cos²(ωt) = 0.016 cos²(8t) J
Both K and U range 0 to 0.016 J; Sum always 0.016 J; Frequency = 2ω = 16 rad/s (double position frequency)
T_energy = T_position/2 = (2π/8)/2 = π/8 = 0.3927 s
K(t) and U(t) are squared sinusoidal functions; Always positive; Out of phase; E_total constant horizontal line
K_max = ½mv_max²; v_max = ωA = 8×0.05=0.4 m/s; K_max=½×0.2×0.16=0.016 J ✓; U_max=½kA²=0.016 J ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: K(t) = 0.016 sin²(8t) J, U(t) = 0.016 cos²(8t) J, E_total = 0.016 J constant; Energy oscillates at double frequency of position

worked_examples.title: Experimental Data Interpretation
worked_examples.problem: Experimental position-time data for an oscillator shows amplitude decreasing from 0.15 m to 0.10 m over 8 complete cycles taking 12 seconds. Determine the damping constant and quality factor.

step_by_step.explanation: 8 cycles in 12 s, so T = 12/8 = 1.5 s
A(t) = A₀e^(-bt/2m); Need mass m? Problem doesn't give m, so express in terms of m

step_by_step.step: Damping constant in terms of mass

step_by_step.explanation: Q = ω₀m/b ≈ ωm/b (for light damping) = 4.1888/0.06758 = 62.0

step_by_step.step: Fraction of energy lost per cycle
step_by_step.explanation: Energy ∝ A²; E(8T)/E₀ = (0.10/0.15)² = 0.4444; Fraction lost in 8 cycles = 0.5556
Fraction remaining per cycle = (0.4444)^(1/8) = 0.9165; Fraction lost per cycle = 1 - 0.9165 = 0.0835
Q = 2π / (fraction lost per cycle) = 6.2832/0.0835 = 75.2
Two methods give Q=62 and Q=75; Difference due to approximation in first method and exponential decay assumptions
Q ≈ 68.5; System is lightly damped

worked_examples.final_answer: Damping constant b/m = 0.0676 s⁻¹, Quality factor Q ≈ 68; Experimental data shows light damping

common_misconceptions: Thinking velocity and position graphs have the same phase
Believing acceleration is maximum when velocity is maximum
Confusing the slope of position graph with position value
Thinking energy graphs have the same frequency as position graphs
Believing all sinusoidal graphs represent SHM
Confusing period with frequency on graphs
Thinking damped oscillations have constant period
summary: Graphical analysis provides powerful tools for understanding simple harmonic motion, with position, velocity, and acceleration graphs exhibiting specific sinusoidal patterns and phase relationships. Position graphs show displacement variation, velocity graphs (slope of position) lead by 90°, and acceleration graphs (slope of velocity) lead by 180°. Energy graphs display kinetic and potential energy oscillating out of phase at double the frequency of position, with total energy remaining constant for ideal systems. Graphical differentiation and integration connect these relationships, while experimental data analysis enables determination of system parameters including damping characteristics. These graphical techniques are essential for analyzing real-world oscillatory systems across physics, engineering, and scientific applications.
